Extreme heat is causing more drownings in France
subhead: The number of drownings at the start of summer 2025 was twice as high as during the same period the previous year. This increase is linked to the early onset of heatwaves, which have driven people to swim in rivers and lakes that are minimally or not at all supervised.

title: Algeria pushes back against Macron's tough line in diplomatic standoff
subhead: After a letter Emmanuel Macron sent to the prime minister, calling for 'more firmness' on matters of 'migration and security with Algeria,' was published, Algeria claimed Paris laid 'all the blame on the Algerian side.'

title: Huge wildfire in southern France now under control
subhead: Authorities said that the most severe fire in France's Mediterranean region in at least 50 years has been contained, though 'There is still a lot of work to be done.' The fire killed one person and destroyed thousands of hectares of land.

title: How Lake Chad became neglected by international aid
subhead: 'Lake Chad's Troubled Waters' (3/4). After a surge of solidarity in response to the attacks by Boko Haram, global attention has shifted away from the region. As NGOs have been weakened by the halt in US funding, the humanitarian situation remains dire.

title: Wildfires blaze in southern France: 'It looked like the apocalypse'
subhead: In the Corbières hills, 16,000 hectares went up in flames in just 24 hours, despite 2,500 firefighters and the mobilization of nearly all of France's aerial resources.

title: Mojgan Habibi, chef: 'Before, I was afraid of everything. Now, I have found my freedom'
subhead: 'Refuge Recipes' (4/6). Iranian native Mojgan Habibi is the breakfast chef at Hôtel du Couvent in Nice. Khoresht mast, a dish reserved for special occasions and made with yogurt, spices, honey and meat, brings back memories of her happy youth in Isfahan before her marriage, when she was free to create and sing.

title: Eva Nguyen Binh, head of the Institut Français: 'Attacking culture has long-term consequences'
subhead: The president of the Institut Français, a French overseas cultural policy actor which has just had its contract renewed, discusses the challenges that cultural diplomacy faces in a time of geopolitical tensions.
